awd_titl_txt: Conference: Elevating Indigenous Knowledges in Ecology
awd_abstract_narration:
For all its advances over the last century, ecology is a relative newcomer as a formal scientific discipline.  Ecologists have developed sophisticated methods and cutting-edge technologies to study the complexities of nature.  Even so, the records they rely on do not go very far back in time, which means that ecologists have a relatively limited view of natural phenomena.  Indigenous knowledges (IKs), or Indigenous Traditional Ecological Knowledge (ITEK), in contrast, provide a much deeper and more holistic perspective on particular places.  These ecological viewpoints allowed Indigenous communities to survive and thrive for millennia prior to European colonization.  The importance of such knowledge has been illustrated in several well-publicized cases, such as fire management in forests of the western United States and Australia.  Ecologists have generally not embraced IKs, but that is beginning to change.  The central problem is that most ecologists do not encounter IKs in their training, nor do they understand the social and ethical challenges in collaborating with Indigenous communities and knowledge holders.  The goal of this workshop is to build a path to IK for ecologists in a way that benefits both scientific inquiry and Indigenous communities.

This workshop will bring together Indigenous scholars and professionals to discuss how to accelerate awareness of the roles of IKs to achieve a better understanding of the natural world and how to do so in a mutually beneficial, reciprocal way.  The workshop will include well-established scholars and professionals, as well as graduate students and early career individuals.  Participants will suggest key elements that all ecologists should know, and areas of concern, such as Indigenous rights and sovereignty, knowledge/data sovereignty, cultural respect, and social and economic issues.  Participants will assemble these elements into a draft outline to be presented to the broader ecological community during an open workshop at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America. The draft outline, plus feedback from the open workshop will be compiled and disseminated through venues such as publications, webinars and one-page summaries.  These products can be incorporated into professional development activities for ecologists at all career stages and will serve as a seed for continued conversations.  Equally important, the resulting products will increase diverse representation and inclusion in the conduct of scientific research and knowledge creation and will expand the research capacity of Indigenous communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Twenty-one Indigenous people, representing 34 Tribal communities from the United States and Canada, convened for two days of intensive discussion about the elevation of Indigenous perspectives in the field of ecology. Four main themes emerged during the 2022 workshop and subsequent careful deliberations: (1) ENGAGE: Ethical protocols and guidelines for reaching and research involving IK; (2) HEAL: Addressing trauma inflicted upon Indigenous Peoples by Settler-Colonial Institutions (SCI); (3) RECONCILE: Elevation of Indigenous scholars and Knowledge holders within SCI; (4) CENTER: Indigenous Knowledges as a central paradigm in SCI.  These ideas are the subject of a paper that should appear in Frontiers in Ecology and the Environment in the coming months.  The paper raises a lot of questions but does not answer them all.  Additional manuscripts are in various stages of completion to address more aspects of these issues.

In answer to the question of how Indigenous Knowledges (IK) can or should be elevated in ecological science and education, the consensus was that that framing was wrong.  As long as IK must exist in a settler-colonial context it will be seen as a marginalized alternative, rather than the co-equal knowledge system that it is.  It is important to understand that this view was arrived at by a diverse (21 individuals who identify with 34 Indigenous communities), but entirely Indigenous group of scholars, without any dictates regarding the end point from non-Indigenous collaborators or organizations (such as ESA).  

The outcomes of this project extend beyond current and planned manuscripts.  Because of the workshop and its perceived value to participants, we have made significant strides in enhancing the community of Indigenous scholars at ESA – their presence at the pre-conference workshop and the ESA annual meeting made a huge difference in the visibility of Indigenous scholars. In 2022 we organized 3 sessions as part of the ESA conference.  In 2023 that number increased to 12, including two contributions by our group members to 2 sessions we did not organize. All TEK-related sessions in 2022 and 2023 were packed, standing room only, overflow crowds.  The caliber of the ecological research and its relevance appears to be garnering increasing attention, indicating the workshop has effectively elevated the perspectives and voices of Indigenous scholars in the ecology community.

The most exciting thing about the sharp increase in sessions between 2022 and 2023 was that all the sessions were organized by Indigenous members, including 3 whose first encounter with ESA was the 2022 meeting, which they only attended because of the workshop report-out panel discussion that followed our 2022 NSF-funded workshop.  All our sessions included Indigenous ecologists who had no prior involvement with ESA or the TEK section, but they were brought in because of workshop participants. 

As a result of these workshops, we see an increased interest, and perhaps acceptance, or at least a willingness to consider Indigenous Knowledges as a legitimate source of knowledge and understanding of the world. We expect the increased number of Indigenous scholars that see an organization such as ESA as a safe and welcoming space will accelerate acceptance, especially as they secure faculty positions and establish their own programs in mainstream universities.  Their work will also expose more Western-trained scientists to TEK/IK and ultimately normalize more expansive and inclusive methodologies and worldviews.  This will take time, but ideas such as Ethical Space that are promoted by Gwen Bridge and James Rattling Leaf provide a path forward.
